facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 325 of 1974 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 325 of 1974.

facts.text: The appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated 8th April 1974 of the Bombay High Court in Crl. Appeal No. 305 of 1974.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 8th April, 1974 of the Bombay High Court in Crl. Appeal No. 305 of 1974.

facts.text: Sharad Manchar, B. P. Maheshwari and Suresh Sethi appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Sharad Manchar, B. P. Maheshwari and Suresh Sethi, for the appellants.

facts.text: B. Wad and M. N. Shroff appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: B. Wad and M. N. Shroff, for the respondent.

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered by JAGANMOHAN REDDY, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANMOHAN REDDY, J.-

facts.text: The Supreme Court admitted the special leave petition and after registration heard the learned advocates for the parties.

anchor.surface_text: We have just number admitted the special leave, petition and after the appeal was registered heard the learned Advocates for the parties.

facts.text: A criminal first appeal against conviction was dismissed summarily by the High Court under Section 421 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: This is yet another case in which a criminal first appeal against a companyviction has been dismissed summarily under Section 421 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: The Supreme Court heard both sides.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard both sides.

facts.text: Mr. Wad for the State contended that the High Court has power to dismiss summarily and cited several decisions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Wad for the State has strenuously companytended that the High Court has power to dismiss summarily and has cited several decisions,

facts.text: The dismissal by the High Court was so summary that even the record was not called for.

anchor.surface_text: It is submitted that the dismissal, was so summary that even the record was number called for.

facts.text: Section 421 Criminal Procedure Code vests power in High Court to dismiss appeal summarily on perusal of petition and copy of judgment.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, Section 421, Criminal Procedure Code does vest a power in the High Court to dismiss an appeal summarily but it can do so only on a perusal of the petition and the companyy of the judgment.

facts.text: There is a long series of decisions beginning from 1953 SCR 809 discouraging summary dismissal by one word 'dismissed'.

anchor.surface_text: Inasmuch as under our Constitution any person aggrieved by an order of the High Court can petition to this Court under Article 136 for special leave, it is number only necessary but having regard to the long series of decisions beginning as far back as 1953  see 1953 SCR 809  onwards which discourages this practice of dismissal by one word dismissed,

facts.text: Arguable points arise in this case as per statements in special leave petition.

anchor.surface_text: Since we are number in a position to ascertain and it is companytended before us that arguable points do arise in this case in support of which the statement made in special leave petition has been read to us,

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court order, and remanded the appeal to the High Court for hearing on admission and disposal in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed. The order of the High Court is set aside. The appeal is remanded to the High Court for hearing for admission and disposal in accordance with law and in the light of the directions made here in above.
This is yet another case in which a criminal first appeal against a companyviction has been dismissed summarily under Section 421 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Summary dismissals without reasons reverse the appellate process, impose unnecessary burden on Supreme Court, cause long avoidable delay and anxiety to convicted persons

anchor.surface_text: we are number in a position to say that an arguable case does number arise. We would have been able to do so even if we had the slightest inkling in the order of the High Court. In the absence of any reasons what has been happening in many cases is that special leave is admitted, and after hearing the appeal if this Court has companye to the companyclusion that the companyviction is valid, it has held that the dismissal by the High Court is justified. But this method, in our view, reverses the process and imposes unnecessary burden on this Court. What should have been done by the High Court, is number being done by this Court. It is only after sending for the records, getting the paper books prepared, hearing both parties in the appeal and after appreciation of the evidence that it may be held that in some cases the dismissal, in fact, was ultimately justified. In many cases the appeals were even allowed. Long avoidable delay thus ensues during which the person companyvicted entertains a doubt about his companyviction and has to suffer the anxiety caused thereby. We do hope and trust that the series of decisions over this long period disapproving of the practice of summarily dismissing by one word will be taken numbere of and this Court will number be ultimately burdened with such appeals arising out of summary dismissals which is really the function of the High Court at the first instance.

holdings.text: Section 421, Criminal Procedure Code does vest a power in the High Court to dismiss an appeal summarily but it can do so only on a perusal of the petition and the copy of the judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application and textual interpretation of Section 421 CrPC limiting the summary dismissal power to perusal of the appeal petition and judgment copy.

holdings.text: Inasmuch as under our Constitution any person aggrieved by an order of the High Court can petition to this Court under Article 136 for special leave, it is not only necessary but having regard to the long series of decisions beginning as far back as 1953 see 1953 SCR 809 onwards which discourages this practice of dismissal by one word dismissed, the High Court should at least have given some reasons why no arguable case is made out on a perusal of those documents.

anchor.surface_text: Inasmuch as under our Constitution any person aggrieved by an order of the High Court can petition to this Court under Article 136 for special leave, it is number only necessary but having regard to the long series of decisions beginning as far back as 1953  see 1953 SCR 809  onwards which discourages this practice of dismissal by one word dismissed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 136 right to seek special leave and consistent Supreme Court precedents discouraging unreasoned one-word dismissals necessitate brief reasons indicating why no arguable case on perusal of documents.

holdings.text: Since we are not in a position to ascertain and it is contended before us that arguable points do arise in this case in support of which the statement made in special leave petition has been read to us, we are not in a position to say that an arguable case does not arise.
